title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this legislation. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, descendants of coastal tribes, have been recognized by the state and Congress as an Indian tribe. They are seeking full Federal recognition to receive benefits and privileges. The Lumbee Indians, a federally recognized Indian tribe, are seeking full Federal recognition to receive benefits and privileges. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and services under laws and regulations applicable to Indian tribes. Other Indian groups in the area can petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will determine needs and budget in consultation with the tribe after verifying the tribal roll. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, will develop a determination of needs and budget for providing services to eligible tribe members based on the tribal roll. The tribal roll, verified by the Secretary of the Interior, will define the service population of the Tribe for the delivery of Federal services. The tribal roll, verified by the Secretary of the Interior, will define the service population of the Tribe for the delivery of Federal services, subject to compliance with membership criteria set out in the Tribe's constitution. The Tribe seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust purposes in Robeson County, North Carolina. The land will be treated as on-reservation trust acquisitions by the Secretary of the Interior. Additionally, state jurisdiction is addressed in the following section. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the state to the United States under an agreement with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe and the State of North Carolina can transfer jurisdiction over their land under an agreement, with a 2-year waiting period for it to take effect. This transfer does not affect the application of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
